Transcribed 10.8.93. To proof.
On 11 August 1866 the Secretary of State for the Colonies, the Earl of Carnarvon, wrote to Henry Manners-Sutton to acknowledge the receipt of a despatch concerning the distinction conferred on M by the Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin. Carnarvon said that he had brought under the consideration of the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs that M was a naturalized foreigner, and that the order was conferred on him by the Sovereign of the Country of his birth, but the Secretary of State still decided against M, (No. 17, unit 20, VPRS 1087, PROV). [Melbourne,]
editorial addition.
17th October 1866.

I am directed by the Governor to inform you that your letter of the 20th May 1866,
M to G. Carey, 20 May 1866. relating to a distinction conferred upon you by the Grand Duke of Mecklenburg Schwerin, was transmitted, by the Officer Administering the Government, to the Right Honorable the Secretary of State.

It appears however that it has long been settled that if a Foreigner obtains British naturalization, or accepts employment in the British Service, so as to render it necessary for him to obtain the Queen's permission to accept and wear Foreign decorations his case must be governed by the Regulations which apply to a British Subject, and however much the Earl of Carnarvon may regret the effect of this rule in your case His Lordship cannot recommend any exception from it.
